Hi Georgios, I hope things are well.  Thanks for sharing your paper. 
The p=
roblem that rtNEAT requires a high level of interaction indeed
constrains t=
he types of scenarios in which it can be effective.  If
the NPCs don't get =
enough interaction, the evaluation is impoverished.
 Thus there is clearly =
a challenge when a single player is the only
focal point of interaction.  H=
owever, if that single player is is in
control of a set of agents, each one=
 of which is a point of
interaction, I think there is hope that the net int=
eraction can be
sufficient.  However, the balance is delicate and the speci=
fics of the
game obviously become important.  Your paper makes a good point=
 by
highlighting this issue and showing that it needs to be considered in
t=
he game design if real-time evolution is to be successful.

ken

--- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "g.yannakakis" <yannakakis@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> =
I thought the following might be of interest to some of you. 
> 
> We recen=
tly presented a paper at the IEEE Computational Intelligence
> and Games 20=
08 symposium where NEAT and rtNEAT are used to dynamically
> adjust the cha=
llenge level of a real-time strategy game.
> 
> Here is the article:
> http=
://www.itu.dk/~yannakakis/cig08_1.pdf
> 
> In a few words, NEAT worked just=
 fine in generating diverse NPC
> behaviors like 'win-fast' and 'produce-ma=
ximum-numbers-of-warriors'.
> rtNEAT, on the other hand did not perform tha=
t well and that fast due
> to insufficient interaction in the RTS game unde=
r investigation. 
> 
> Comments and feedback are more than welcome.
> 
> Re=
gards
> Georgios
>
